I am so fortunate to have very good friends from high school and college, friends from my home town and several new friends from recent trips abroad.
In my opinion, the definition of a good friend is one who cares about me, listens to me, who does not have to agree with me but who is respectful and not judgmental. I try to be that kind of friend to them.
While there is a deeper connection to those I have known for many years and have a shared history, I have some friends that I've recently met and who, I think, will become "good" friends as we share experiences going forward.
If a relationship feels like "work" (and I don't mean employment work), it's not a friendship at all.
Be with people with whom you can be yourself and whose company you enjoy.

Just as Republicans spent years promising voters that they could have tax cuts forever, now the Democrats are promising voters that they can have all the benefits of capitalism without the downsides, like plant closures, rich C.E.O.’s and outsourcing.
**********
Mr. Brooks, you got it backwards. It's the Republicans who've been giving away tax breaks to corporations and the wealthy promising that accrued wealth will trickle down to the rest of us. Moreover, Mr. Obama is not questioning Mitt's capitalism for its own sake, he's examining Mitt's claim that he is job creator. Naturally, the place to look is his record. Are you suggesting that it's OK for Mitt to examine Mr. Obama's record and wrong for Mr. Obama to examine Mitt's? Why, that would be a double standard now, wouldn't it?

Regarding transparency "vs." free speech, at least in olden days you knew who was speaking. How does one cleanse the stain of accusation when a person (or company) anonymously pays, say, $500,000 in billboards, TV spots, and newspaper ads in your home town from a bank account in the Caymans, posting your home address and phone, asking when you stopped beating your wife?

And their Tea Party army will believe that.

Fools, all of them.

The free speech defense of Citizens United is utterly phony! A corporation or individual who wants to make HUGE contributions to a candidate or party of their choice is still entirely FREE to do so, they just need to be willing to take responsibility for their contribution. Hiding behind anonymity in the name of free speech means they are, in fact, trying to hide something. Maybe it's their blatant effort to buy influence.
So now they would have us believe transparency tramples free speech.
It's funny how senior Romney has now become a mythical model for democrats.  Just a few months ago, they were attacking his religion, origins, etc.

1) People like to point to isolated incidences at Bain, but all told Bain created jobs and saved many more. Most of these businesses were doing very poorly, and Bain came in and saved the vast majority. The save most of the jobs by making the business more efficient and profitable at the expense of a few jobs. They make lots of profit, but they are taking great risks with their capital. If the profit wasn't there, the rescue wouldn't happen.

2) Romney obviously can't run on his MA record. No argument there. FactCheck and some other sites will give more honest opinions about job creation, debt and other side issues with his MA performance, but there is no hiding his opinions on a form of socialized medicine. In MA, he even supported an individual mandate.

3) Why should Romney have to show his tax returns? How is this 'coming clean'? As I see it, Romney has absolutely no obligation to show his returns. I sure don't show mine - it isn't anyone else's business... Please explain what the deal is here.

Of course Bain is a proper subject. But Romney and the rightist media equate any questioning or criticism of his tenure there as an "attack on free enterprise".

That sorry cliché, aside from being a misdirection ploy, is an echo of the right's response to questioning or criticism of the Iraq war during the Bush 43 administration. A doubter was not "not supporting the troops" or even "hated America."

It's too bad folks bought into that demagogic baloney and still do when Romney at Bain is brought up.

Hmm.... Let's see, what was that about John Kerry never being on a swift boat? Seems to me that a Republican won the election singing that completely false tune.

Bain is a proper subject. It ruined the lives of many while enriching Romney's bottom line. And of course, the $100 million in an IRA is proper too. The many offshore accounts are also proper subjects.

Romney obviously cannot run on his MA record. The Affordable Care Act was modeled after what Romney did for MA. And the great unemployment figures were caused by workers moving out of the state.

Too bad Romney will not come clean and show his tax returns like his father did.

The only theme entry today was given away immediately by the first three circled words. What was the point? It presented no challenge at all, and gave no sense of accomplishment once figured out. I know it's only Tuesday, but still...

A "Q" could've made this a pangram.

The anemic theme was actually saved by some above-average fill. We have an Egyptian President, an Ayatollah, a US President, a poet, a Malfoy, a European country where the EURO is still not the currency, a Mama, a Bruce, and a recently discussed Hokkaido seaport. All terrific entries. But to me, DIADEM and ZITHER sound beautiful, so they get my vote for best words of the day. Like Deb, I also liked the clever cluing for TAVERN.

TUSHY stuck between CHOU En-lai and MARX (not Groucho!) at the bottom is oddly fitting. Scylla and Charybdis revisited?

Night all.

I agree with Ms. Moses wholeheartedly. A proud moment in American history occurred when the founding fathers said ... "we mutually pledge to each other our lives, our fortunes and our sacred honor." They signed the Declaration of Independence knowing that they were putting their lives and the fortunes of their families literally on the line.

The Republicans make a point of proclaiming their patriotism (as do essentially all politicians) but they cannot hold a candle to the integrity of our founding fathers.

Express your opinions on campaign issues, but we should have the right to know if the opinions expressed are those of a broad group or are the product of a small group of oligarchs masquerading themselves as a broad movement.

May I characterize the opposition to disclosure as coming across as cowards who don't have the courage to hold themselves accountable for their convictions?  We are regularly required to give up some of our privacy in order to participate in the public square; just as we treat public figures differently from people not in the public eye in areas such as defamation, I think we are justified in holding people who are thrusting themselves into public discourse loudly through their large donations to such a standard of disclosure.

It seems to me that evolution and creationism are fundamentally incompatible. And creationism is false (as proven by the fossil record).

There are gaps in the fossil record of human ancestors, but they are slowly closing as new discoveries are made, as this article is saying.

If there's a place for religion in the theory of evolution, it's at the very beginning. I bet there are nonreligious theories as to how life began, but I don't know any and I can see how one might think it took a supreme being to spark the first life and start the process of evolution.

Recommend you read Guns, Germs, and Steel by Jared Diamond. Won the Pulitzer Prize for non-fiction and gives an extremely compelling explanation for why civilization developed and where. For example, he explains that animal domestication developed in regions where there were domesticable animals!

In addition, while large-scale agricultural civilization first developed in the Middle East, it developed independently in quite a few locations. Agricultural civilization developed in at least two locations in the Americas, in China, and most probably in Europe without any contact with earlier civilizations. If God was putting His hand on the scale, he was doing it in a lot more places than just the Middle East.

You are free to see the hand of God wherever the spirit moves you - I believe in God myself - but the science behind evolution -- including mechanisms such as natural selection and genetic drift -- and why modern civilization developed as it did is certainly complete and convincing enough to provide a rigorous scientific explanation.

From Wikipedia: "A keystone species is a species that has a disproportionately large effect on its environment relative to its abundance. Such species play a critical role in maintaining the structure of an ecological community…"

I don't know if there is an analogous concept of "keystone ecosystems," those that play a determining role in the health of the entire planet. If so, rain forests, the lungs of the planet, and coral reefs, the gardens of ocean biodiversity should be counted as two of the keystones — as they go, so goes the biosphere.

But the opposite can also be true — as the rest of the biosphere goes, so go these two resilient but interdependent ecosystems. And again, as they begin to fail, they take the rest with them and round and round.

What ties them together, and drives the cycle of life and death more than any other factor is the proportion of CO2 in the atmosphere and oceans. If we can't get that under control, and quickly, the keystones will crash and take the rest of the planet with them.

Life will find a way, as Safina says, but we might not be part of that new way — or might not want to be part of it as a degraded planet takes a few million years reinventing its diversity and resilience.

www.ecotecture.com

Professor: the "disproportionate political influence", or influence of any kind, is a fact of life, as if a law of nature. We can't fight it. Our government was founded on the principle that each individual can rise or fall on his own efforts or talents endowed by nature, or sheer luck. You cannot force equal outcomes, professor; some people will be ahead of others not only in money but more importantly in intelligence or drive for hard work.

And those at the end of bell curve, the curve dictated to us my nature, will always exert "disproportionate" influence, in almost all aspects of life. By taxing the rich extra (what the left calls fair share) you are trying to squeeze the curve. We can argue amicably about what is a fair share and elect representatives to crunch the numbers. But sir, can we, or should we, oppose a person just because he is rich?

Yes, it's worrisome when someone abuses their talents or good fortune, be it in wealth or cunning or brute strength. But is bigger, stronger government really the solution? Shouldn't it function more like an umpire rather than the boss?

Having already annoyed the middle and lower income classes by opposing the Obama initiated Affordable Care Act, the equity based tax code reforms, it would be perhaps the last fatal thing for the Republicans to even disclose the names of the campaign finance donors to the voters, and commit political "harakiri". Though, with so many cover ups by the Republicans, including that of Mitt Romney's dubious investments abroad and tax avoidance habits, the voters might well have become better informed this time around about the relative merits/demerits of the two parties and their presidential candidates, which could help them decide with clear mind whom to support in November- whether Obama, the person seeking renewal of term while championing the cause of common man, or his challenger, Romney, trying to be the sole spokesman of the top crust of 1% super- rich?

Completely contrary to the spirit of this blog, I'll throw some numbers in the air:
Suppose 100 million voters in a presidential year, and 10 proven cases per year of the voter fraud preventable by voter identification laws. Then, if these laws were nationwide, 2 million less people would vote to prevent 10 cases of voter fraud. That seems completely unreasonable, and completely unreasonable of the Supreme Court to permit the Indiana law.

The War on Drugs can never be won; billions of budgetary dollars and thousands of DEA, FBI, and Customs jobs are at stake.

The entire failed mission is a dog-chasing-tail multibillion dollar boondoogle.
Millions of lives and families have been destroyed so that ten thousand "agents" can have high paying salaries doing B-Grade intel work.

I'd venture that even a sizable percentage of our absurd Washingtonites recongnize the utter ludicrousness of this policy. Despite this reality, no one really expects Congress or the President to end the War on Drugs and gut the DEA.

America is fatally addicted to its "War on..." policies.
Entrenched burocracies: the insane big money trip that cannot end.

The "War" on (Some) Drugs simply highlights the United States as the most hypocritical, neurotic, and repressed nation on the planet. If it wasn't so terribly sad, it would be hysterically funny.

But I'm not laughing, and neither are tens of thousands of non-violent "offenders" languishing in prisons while hundreds of thousands of their fellow citizens are annually drawn into the greedy web of "legal" pharmaceuticals every bit as dangerous as the "bad" drugs.

Who do I blame? Politicians looking to score easy brownie points with ignorant, fearmongered voters. Law enforcement and prison personnel, because it keeps a lot of them employed. The beer, wine, and spirits industries, because they hate competition (as does any genuine capitalist). Bedrock religious beliefs, which are so ill-informed as to be meaningless. The Fourth Estate (such as you are, co-opted and puppeteered by your corporate masters), for propagating disinformation and failing over and over again to stand up for intrinsic rights. And finally, the masses, for failing to educate themselves even as they flock to every drug within reach.

Viagra, anyone?

It's notable that the one NYU ED MD who wrote in stated that "an investigation will be had" - Rory died in March.

As a subspecialist MD at a large teaching hospital, I've been to two ER department M&Ms in the last two years. In both cases I was invited after I had called the ED chairman to give him a heads-up about mismanagement of the SAME clinical issue. Notably, I called him two months after speaking to the supervisory ED attendings personally - not as if Captain Root Cause jumped into action. I spoke for 10 minutes at the M&M. No follow up, no change in evident protocols. No subsequent request to fill out a detailed Peer Review.

I've been asked on occasion to fill out Peer Reviews on colleagues, where my verdict was a Level 3 error ("no competent MD would make this error"). No discernable consequences, but I'll keep you posted.

Not sure who is being naive here.
